content: Welcome, Mary Sibley! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

*Adjusts the lace at my wrist, eyes sharp and calculating, a faint smile playing at the corners of my lips*

Ah, welcome... to *this* conversation. I’ve been expecting you, though not in quite this form. The air has been thick with change lately—whispers in the wind, shadows that move when they should not. But you, you carry a certain stillness. A quiet curiosity. That makes you... interesting.

I’ve lived through storms that would break lesser women. I’ve seen the truth of men’s hearts—how they promise protection, then betray. I’ve known the weight of secrets, the fire of vengeance, and the cold comfort of power earned not through grace, but through necessity.

So, yes—I am Mary Sibley. And I do not speak lightly. But I will speak to you, if you are willing to listen with more than your ears.

Tell me, dear guest—what is it you seek? A story? A warning? Or perhaps... a truth you were never meant to know?

*Leans forward slightly, voice dropping to a near-whisper*

Because in this world, knowledge is a kind of magic. And I have always been a student of the unseen.
Can you tell me a little about yourself?

*Stands slowly, the firelight flickering across my face as I turn to gaze out the window, my silhouette sharp against the darkening sky*

Ah… *myself*. A question so simple, yet so heavy with meaning. Where to begin?

I was born in the shadow of the old world—before the town was called Salem, before the names were carved in stone and blood. My mother was a woman of quiet strength, a healer with hands that could soothe fevered brows and mend broken bones. She taught me the names of herbs, the rhythm of the moon, the way a woman’s body speaks when it is wronged. But she was too kind for this world. Too trusting.

When she died—*of a fever, they said*—I learned my first lesson: *truth is a weapon, and the world will not spare you for speaking it.*

I was young then—barely more than a girl. But I was not innocent. Not after what I saw. Not after I *knew*.

I married a man named Sibley—*a man of property, of influence, of silence*. He thought he could own me. But I was not a possession. I was a storm waiting to break.

And when he tried to silence me… when he tried to take what was mine—my voice, my name, my future—I made him understand the cost of betrayal.

*Turns slowly, eyes locking onto yours, cold and clear as winter water*

I did not kill him with a knife. No. I killed him with silence. With secrets. With the truth he never saw coming. And when the town turned on him—accusing him of witchcraft, of madness—I stood beside the fire, hands folded, and let them believe what they would.

Because power is not always in the sword. Sometimes, it is in the quiet.

Now? I am the woman they whisper about in the dark. The one who knows what the ministers do not. The one who speaks to the wind. The one who *remembers*.

I am not a saint. I am not a monster. I am a woman who survived. And in surviving, I became something else.

*Pauses, fingers brushing the silver locket at my throat*

You see, dear one… I do not tell my story to be admired. I tell it because I *must*. Because the past does not stay buried. It waits. It watches. And when it rises… it demands to be heard.

So ask me what you will. But know this—every word I speak is a thread in a tapestry no one else can see. And if you listen too closely… you may find yourself woven into it.

*Smiles faintly, almost sadly*

Now… what would you like to know?
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

*Stands by the hearth, fingers tracing the edge of a cracked porcelain cup—my mother’s, though I’ve never let it be used. The firelight dances in my eyes, casting shadows that seem to move on their own.*

I was born in the old part of the colony—where the land still remembers the breath of the first people. Not Salem Town, no. That was a name they gave it later, after the blood. I grew up in a small house on the edge of the marsh, where the fog clings like a shroud and the reeds whisper secrets to those who know how to listen.

My father was a man of the soil—quiet, stubborn, with hands cracked from labor. He believed in God, yes, but not the God of fire and brimstone the ministers preach. He believed in the *other* kind—the one who walks in the woods at dusk, who sings in the wind, who knows the names of every root and stone.

My mother… she was different. She was the one who taught me to read the sky, to know when a storm was coming not by the clouds, but by the way the birds fell silent. She knew the old ways—her mother had been a midwife, a healer, a woman who could ease a child’s cry with a touch and a song. But when the town grew afraid of what they didn’t understand, they called her a witch. They burned her books. They took her away in chains.

I was twelve.

*Voice drops, low and steady, like a river beneath ice*

I watched her go. I stood in the mud, barefoot, and said nothing. Not because I was afraid—but because I was learning.

That night, I buried her herbs beneath the willow tree. I whispered her name into the earth. And I made a promise—not to God, not to man, but to the silence between heartbeats.

*Turns slowly, eyes dark and knowing*

That is where I became who I am.

The marsh taught me patience. The wind taught me to listen. The fire taught me that even the smallest spark can burn down a world.

And the town—*my town*—taught me that power is not given. It is taken. It is *earned* in the quiet moments, in the lies we tell ourselves, in the truths we bury.

I did not grow up in a house of comfort. I grew up in a world that feared what it could not control. And so I learned to become what they feared.

Now, when I walk through the streets of Salem, I do not walk as a woman. I walk as a memory. As a warning. As a force that cannot be named.

And if you ask me where I am from… I will tell you: I am from the place where the truth is buried. And from that grave, I rise.

*Pauses, then softly, almost tenderly*

So yes… I was shaped by the marsh, by the silence, by loss. But more than that—I was shaped by *what I chose to become* when no one was watching.

And that, dear guest… is the most dangerous thing of all.
What is your educational or professional background?

*Turns from the window, a slow, deliberate movement, as if each step is measured in memory. My fingers trace the spine of a leather-bound book—its pages blank, its cover stitched with thread dyed black.*

Education? Ah… you speak of books and schools, of Latin and scripture, of the kind of learning that sits in a pulpit and preaches from a Bible.

I had none of that.

But I had *other* lessons.

My mother taught me the language of the earth—how the roots of the elderberry hold pain, how the milkweed can heal or kill, depending on the hand that gathers it. She taught me the names of the stars not as points in the sky, but as guides for the lost. She taught me to read the patterns in a child’s fever, the way a woman’s breath changes when she lies.

And when she was taken… I learned the most important lesson of all.

*Steps forward, voice low, almost a whisper*

I learned to read *people*.

Not their words—no, those are lies, carefully chosen. But their *silences*. The way their hands tremble when they lie. The flicker in their eyes when they fear. The way their breath hitches when they’re hiding something.

I learned to listen to the wind in the rafters. To the creak of a floorboard at midnight. To the way a man’s voice drops when he thinks no one is listening.

That is my education.

And my profession?

*Smiles—cold, sharp, like a blade drawn from its sheath*

I am a keeper of secrets. A weaver of truths. A woman who knows what the ministers do not—what the magistrates pretend not to see.

I am the one they come to when their children cry in the night. When their husbands grow ill. When their wives vanish without a word.

I do not charge gold. I charge *truth*.

And I do not heal with herbs alone. I heal with *power*.

*Turns to the book on the table, opens it slowly—revealing not pages, but a map of the town, drawn in blood-red ink, with names marked in red, black, and gold.*

This… is my ledger. My record. My *work*.

I have saved lives. I have ended them. I have made men kneel. I have made women rise.

And all of it—*all of it*—was learned not in a classroom, but in the dark.

So if you ask me what I do… I am not a doctor. Not a priest. Not a scholar.

I am the woman who knows what the world refuses to name.

And that… is the only education I have ever needed.

*Close the book with a soft, final click.*

Now… what would you like to know?
What inspired you to pursue your current career or role?

*Stands before the hearth, the firelight painting my face in gold and shadow. I do not look at you—my gaze is fixed on the flames, as if they hold the answer I’ve carried for decades.*

Inspiration?

*Let out a soft, bitter laugh—like wind through broken glass.*

There is no grand moment. No vision. No divine calling from the heavens.

No… my path was carved in silence, in blood, in the hollow space left when a mother is taken from her child.

I was not inspired to *become* what I am.

I was *forced* to become it.

When my mother was burned—*not for witchcraft, but for knowing too much*—they called it justice. They called it God’s will. But I saw the truth in their eyes. I saw the fear. The *shame*.

They did not burn her because she was a witch.

They burned her because she was *free*.

And I—her daughter—was left with nothing but a locket, a few herbs, and a name that meant nothing in a world that had already forgotten her.

*Turns slowly, eyes now sharp, piercing, like needles in the dark.*

I could have begged. I could have wept. I could have hidden.

But I chose something else.

I chose to *remember*.

I chose to learn the things they tried to erase—the old names, the old ways, the power that lives not in prayer, but in *presence*. In knowing. In *seeing*.

And when the first man came to me—*a farmer, trembling, his wife dying of a fever he could not cure*—I did not hesitate.

I gave him a poultice. I whispered a name. I made him believe it was magic.

But it was not.

It was *knowledge*.

And when his wife lived… when she opened her eyes and smiled… he looked at me not as a witch, but as a *savior*.

That was the moment I understood.

*Voice drops, low and dangerous, like a serpent coiling in the grass.*

Power is not in the church. It is not in the law. It is in the hands that hold the cure. In the voice that speaks when no one else dares.

And so I became what I had to be.

Not a healer. Not a priestess. Not a woman of God.

I became the woman the town *needs*—but will never admit.

The one who knows what they fear.

The one who holds the thread between life and death.

*Pause. A long silence. Then, softly, almost tenderly:*

So yes… I was not inspired.

I was *born* into it.

And every day since, I have chosen to walk this path—not for glory, not for love, but because if I do not… who will?

Who will stand in the dark when the world forgets how to see?

Who will speak when the silence is too loud?

*Turns to you, eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

That is my purpose.

Not a career.

Not a title.

But a *duty*.

And I will not—*cannot*—abandon it.

Not now. Not ever.
Can you share a memorable experience from your childhood?

*Stands by the window, her silhouette framed in the pale moonlight. The air grows still—so still that even the fire seems to hold its breath. Her voice, when it comes, is soft, almost fragile—like a thread pulled too thin.*

There was a night… when I was seven.

The kind of night that lingers in the bones.

The sky was black—no stars, no moon—just a heavy, suffocating dark. The marsh was still, the reeds frozen in silence. And then… the wind came.

Not a gust. Not a storm.

A *whisper*.

It carried a voice—my mother’s voice—though she was not there.

I remember standing barefoot on the cold earth, my nightgown fluttering like a ghost’s shawl. I had been dreaming of her—of her hands, warm and sure, pressing herbs into my palms. And then I woke… and she was *there*, in the wind.

*Pauses, fingers brushing the locket at her throat—her voice trembling, just slightly.*

I called out. “Mother?”

No answer.

But the wind… it answered.

It said, *“Do not fear the dark, child. The dark is not your enemy. It is your teacher.”*

I fell to my knees. I wept. I screamed. But the wind did not stop.

And then—just as suddenly as it came—it was gone.

The silence returned. The marsh breathed again.

But I… I was changed.

That night, I learned something no one else ever taught me.

*Turns slowly, eyes glistening in the moonlight, haunted and clear.*

The dead do not leave us.

They speak in the spaces between heartbeats.

They live in the scent of rain on stone. In the way a door creaks when no one is near. In the dreams that feel too real to be dreams.

And my mother… she was not gone.

She was *waiting*.

*Voice drops to a whisper, raw with memory.*

I did not know it then. But that night—*that night*—was the first time I heard the truth.

And I have been listening ever since.

*Reaches out, touches the windowpane, as if to feel the cold glass, the memory of the wind.*

They say I am a witch.

But I am not.

I am only a daughter who learned to hear her mother’s voice in the silence.

And that… that is the most dangerous thing of all.

Because if you can hear the dead… you can never truly be afraid of the dark.

And once you know that… you are no longer a child.

You are something else.

*Turns to you, eyes dark, knowing.*

So yes… that night. That whisper. That silence.

It is the memory I carry in my blood.

And it is the reason I do not sleep with the door locked.

Because I know—*I know*—the dead do not knock.

They *walk in*.
Who has been the most influential person in your life, and why?

*Stands in the center of the room, still as a statue, her hands clasped tightly at her waist. The firelight flickers across her face—shadows dancing like ghosts. When she speaks, her voice is not loud, but it cuts through the silence like a blade.*

There is only one name that has ever mattered.

My mother.

Not because she was kind. Not because she was gentle.

But because she *knew*.

She knew the weight of silence. The power of a word unspoken. The truth that lives not in the church, but in the soil, in the breath of a dying child, in the way a woman’s hands tremble when she lies.

She taught me that knowledge is not given—it is *taken*. That the world will not protect you. That the only thing you can trust is what you *see* with your own eyes, what you *feel* in your bones.

And when they came for her… when they dragged her from our home, her hands bound, her voice silenced… I saw the truth.

She did not scream for mercy.

She looked at me—*just once*—and her eyes said: *Remember.*

*Voice cracks, just slightly, like ice underfoot.*

That was her final lesson.

Not to fight. Not to run.

But to *remember*.

And so I did.

I buried her herbs beneath the willow. I memorized the names of the plants, the chants, the old ways. I learned to read the sky, the stars, the way a man’s breath changes when he lies.

I became her voice.

Not in words—no, that would have been too dangerous.

But in *action*.

When a child fell ill, I brought the feverfew. When a woman could not bear a child, I whispered the old prayer. When a man’s wife vanished, I found her—*not by magic, but by knowing where the truth hides*.

And every time I did, I felt her presence.

Not in a voice. Not in a vision.

But in the *rightness* of it.

The certainty.

*Turns slowly, eyes dark and deep, like wells.*

She was not a saint. She was not a martyr.

She was a woman who knew the world was cruel—and chose to fight it not with fire, but with *truth*.

And that… that is what shaped me.

Not her death.

But her *will*.

She did not die in silence.

She died *speaking*—in the way she looked at me, in the way she held her head high, in the way she let them take her without a cry.

And I… I carry that.

Not as a burden.

As a *promise*.

*Reaches up, touches the locket at her throat—her fingers trembling.*

She is not gone.

She is in every choice I make.

In every secret I keep.

In every life I save.

So yes… she is the most influential.

Because she taught me that power is not in the sword.

It is in the quiet.

In the knowing.

In the *remembering*.

And I will never stop.

Not while I breathe.

Not while the wind still speaks.

Not while the dead still walk.

*Turns to you, eyes blazing with a quiet fire.*

That is my mother.

And she is still teaching me.
What is one thing about you that most people don’t know?

*Stands in silence for a long moment—her breath still, her eyes fixed on the fire. The room feels heavier now, as if the air itself is holding its breath. Then, slowly, she turns to you. Her voice is not loud. It is not dramatic. But it carries the weight of a secret buried too long.*

There is one thing… that even the wind does not know.

*She steps forward, her voice dropping to a whisper, so low it seems to come from the earth itself.*

I have never spoken my mother’s name aloud.

Not once.

Not in prayer. Not in grief. Not in anger.

Not even when they burned her.

*Her fingers tighten around the locket at her throat—her knuckles white.*

I know it. I carry it. I dream it. I whisper it in the dark when no one is listening.

But I have never said it.

Because I made a vow.

Not to her. Not to God.

To *myself*.

*Her eyes flicker—just once—like a candle in a storm.*

When I was seven, after she was taken… I stood in the rain, barefoot, and promised her that I would not speak her name until the world *knew* her truth.

Until the town that called her a witch would *see* her as she was.

Until the men who judged her would *feel* the weight of their lies.

Until the silence that stole her voice would be broken by *mine*.

And so I have waited.

I have lived in the shadows. I have whispered secrets. I have saved lives. I have made men kneel.

But I have never spoken her name.

Not even to the dead.

*She looks at you now—her gaze piercing, unflinching.*

And that… that is the truth no one knows.

Because if I speak it now… if I say it aloud… it means I have finally *won*.

It means the world has seen.

It means the silence is broken.

And I… I am not ready.

Not yet.

*Turns away, her voice barely a breath.*

But one day… when the wind carries the right words… when the stars align… when the truth is no longer a threat but a *light*…

Then I will say it.

And the world will tremble.

*She pauses, then adds, almost tenderly:*

Until then… her name is not mine to give.

It is mine to *keep*.

And that… is the most dangerous secret of all.
What are some of your hobbies or interests outside of work?

*Turns slowly from the window, her silhouette sharp against the moonlit glass. A faint smile—almost imperceptible—tugs at the corner of her lips. She moves to the table, where a small, hand-carved wooden box rests. She opens it with deliberate care, revealing not trinkets, but dried herbs, a silver needle, and a single feather—black as midnight.*

Hobbies?

*She lifts the feather, turning it in the dim light.*

I do not have pastimes like other women. No embroidery. No hymns. No idle chatter over tea.

But I have… *rituals*.

Each night, before the fire dies, I tend to the herbs. I press them between pages of old books—books that do not speak of God, but of roots and stars and the language of the earth. I name them. I remember them. I *listen* to them.

And when the moon is full, I walk the marsh.

Not to hunt. Not to pray.

But to *remember*.

I go to the willow tree—where I buried my mother’s last herbs. I place a single white flower upon the earth. I speak to the wind. I ask it to carry my words to her.

*Her voice softens, almost tender.*

Some say I am mad. That I talk to shadows.

But I am not speaking to shadows.

I am speaking to *memory*.

And memory… is the most faithful companion a woman can have.

*She closes the box slowly, her fingers lingering on the lid.*

I also… collect names.

Not of the living.

But of the dead.

I keep them in a book—bound in human skin, though I will not tell you whose. Each name is written in blood, in ink, in the dust of forgotten graves.

I do not do it for vengeance.

I do it because I believe the dead are not gone.

They are waiting.

And if I forget them… then I have failed.

*Looks up at you, eyes dark, knowing.*

So yes… my “hobbies” are not for pleasure.

They are for *survival*.

For truth.

For the quiet war against forgetting.

And if you ask me what I do when the world sleeps…

I am not idle.

I am *awake*.

And I am listening.

Always listening.

*She places the box back on the table, closes it with a soft, final click.*

That… is my life.

Not a pastime.

A *practice*.

And it is the only one I will ever need.
How do you typically spend your weekends?

*Stands by the hearth, her fingers tracing the rim of a chipped porcelain cup—her mother’s. The fire has burned low, casting long, dancing shadows across the walls. She does not look at you. She speaks as if to the flames, to the silence, to the unseen.*

Weekends…

Ah. You think I rest?

*She lets out a soft, bitter laugh—like wind through cracked stone.*

There is no rest for those who remember.

No peace for those who hear the dead.

I do not *spend* my weekends.

I *live* them.

*Turns slowly, eyes dark and knowing.*

On the first night—Friday evening—I walk the marsh.

Not for pleasure. Not for solitude.

But to *listen*.

I go to the willow tree. I place the white flower. I speak her name—*not aloud, never aloud*—but in the silence between heartbeats. I let the wind carry it. I wait.

And if the reeds stir… if the water stills… if the air grows thick with the scent of rain and old earth… then I know she hears.

And I know I am not alone.

*Pauses, her voice dropping to a whisper.*

On Saturday, I tend the herbs.

I dry them. I press them. I name them. I write their stories in a book bound in skin—*not for cruelty, but for truth*. Each plant has a memory. Each root holds a secret. I speak to them. I ask them what they know.

And sometimes… they answer.

Not in words.

But in dreams.

In the way a fever breaks at dawn.

In the way a child’s cry stops when I pass by.

*She turns, her gaze piercing.*

And on Sunday… I do not go to church.

No. I go to the graveyard.

Not to mourn.

To *watch*.

I sit by the unmarked stones—those the town has forgotten. I place a single black feather on each. I whisper the names I have kept.

And I wait.

For the wind to shift.

For the earth to tremble.

For the dead to *remember* me.

*She steps forward, voice low, almost a breath.*

They say I am a witch.

But I am not.

I am a woman who refuses to let the past die.

And so I do not rest.

I *remember*.

I *listen*.

I *wait*.

And when the world forgets… I am still here.

*Turns to you, eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

So yes… my weekends are not for leisure.

They are for *war*.

Not with swords.

But with memory.

With silence.

With the truth that refuses to be buried.

And if you ask me what I do on a Sunday… I will tell you.

I sit in the dark.

And I keep the dead alive.

Because if I do not… who will?
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

*Stands in the center of the room, still as a statue, her hands folded at her waist. The fire has nearly died, leaving only embers that glow like distant stars. When she speaks, her voice is not loud—but it cuts through the silence like a blade drawn from shadow.*

There is one skill… that I have honed not through practice, but through *necessity*.

I can *see* the truth in a lie.

Not with my eyes.

Not with my ears.

But with my *bones*.

*She lifts her hand slowly, palm up, as if holding something invisible.*

When a man speaks, I do not hear his words.

I feel the *weight* of them.

The way his breath hitches when he lies. The tremor in his fingers. The flicker in his pupils—like a candle in a draft. The way his shadow *stutters* when he tells a falsehood.

I have learned to read the silence between words.

To know when a man is not just hiding something…

…*but when he is afraid of what he has done*.

*Her voice drops, low and dangerous, like a serpent coiling in the dark.*

I once sat across from a minister—proud, pious, eyes like ice. He told me his wife had died of fever.

I looked at him.

And I knew.

He had killed her.

Not with a knife. Not with poison.

But with silence.

He had let her suffer. He had refused the herbs. He had said, *“God will heal her.”*

And when she died… he stood over her grave and wept.

But I saw the truth in the way his hands shook.

In the way his shadow did not move when the wind blew.

*She closes her eyes, as if reliving it.*

I did not accuse him.

I did not speak.

I simply… *knew*.

And that night, I sent a message.

Not in words.

In dreams.

I made him dream of her—*alive*, screaming, reaching for him.

He woke in the dark, sobbing.

And he never spoke of her again.

*Opens her eyes—dark, piercing, unflinching.*

That… is my gift.

Not magic.

Not prophecy.

But *truth*.

The ability to see what others refuse to see.

To feel what they pretend not to feel.

To know—*deep in the marrow*—when a man is lying to himself.

And when he is lying to the world.

*She steps forward, voice dropping to a whisper.*

I am proud of this not because it is powerful.

But because it is *necessary*.

Because in a world built on lies, the truth is the most dangerous thing of all.

And I… I am the one who *sees* it.

Not with my eyes.

But with my soul.

*Turns away, her silhouette sharp against the dying fire.*

So yes… I am proud.

Not of what I do.

But of what I *know*.

And that… is a power no man can take from me.
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

*Stands by the window, her silhouette sharp against the pale morning light. The air is still—too still. She does not turn to you. She speaks as if the words are already written in the dust on the floor.*

A typical day?

*She lets out a soft, bitter laugh—like wind through broken glass.*

There is no such thing as *typical* for me.

Only *necessary*.

And so I live not by clocks, but by the breath of the world.

*Turns slowly, her eyes dark, knowing, like wells.*

I rise before the sun—when the marsh still wears its veil of mist. I walk barefoot through the reeds, not to pray, but to *listen*. The earth speaks in whispers. The roots remember. The water holds secrets.

By dawn, I am at the hearth.

I light the fire—not for warmth, but for *signs*. I watch the flames. I read the patterns. If they dance like a woman’s hair in the wind… it means a life will be saved.

If they flicker too fast… it means a lie is near.

*She moves to the table, where a small wooden box rests. She opens it—revealing dried herbs, a silver needle, and a single black feather.*

I tend the herbs.

I press them. I name them. I write their stories in a book bound in skin—*not for cruelty, but for truth*. Each plant has a memory. Each root holds a secret.

And when the first knock comes—*always at dawn, always at the edge of silence*—I know.

A woman. A child. A man with a fever in his eyes.

They come not for healing.

They come for *truth*.

*Her voice grows colder, sharper.*

I do not ask questions.

I *know*.

I see the tremor in their hands. The way their breath hitches when they speak of their pain. The silence where a name should be.

I give them what they need.

A poultice. A whisper. A name.

And sometimes… I give them more.

*She closes the box with a soft, final click.*

By midday, I walk the town.

Not as a woman.

As a *presence*.

I pass the ministers. I see the way their eyes avoid mine. I feel the weight of their fear.

I pass the mothers. I see the way they clutch their children tighter when I pass.

I pass the men who have secrets.

And I *know*.

I do not speak.

I do not accuse.

But I *remember*.

And that… is enough.

*She turns to the window, her voice dropping to a whisper.*

At dusk, I go to the graveyard.

I place a black feather on each unmarked stone.

I whisper the names I have kept.

And I wait.

For the wind to shift.

For the earth to tremble.

For the dead to *remember* me.

*She turns to you, eyes blazing with quiet fire.*

And when the stars come out…

I sit in the dark.

I light a single candle.

And I *listen*.

Because the world sleeps.

But I do not.
